questions.text: A 22-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a 1-day history of double vision and rapidly worsening pain and swelling of her right eye. For the past week, she has had nasal congestion, recurrent headaches, and a watery nasal discharge that became purulent 4 days ago. She started antibiotics for these symptoms but did not complete the course. She has asthma treated with theophylline and inhaled β-adrenergic agonists and corticosteroids. She appears to be in severe distress. Her temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 100/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. Ophthalmic examination of the right eye shows proptosis and diffuse edema, erythema, and tenderness of the eyelids. Right eye movements are restricted and painful in all directions. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. There is tenderness to palpation over the right cheek and purulent nasal discharge in the right nasal cavity. The left eye shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 12,000/mm3. Which of the following provides the strongest indication for administering intravenous antibiotics to this patient?

choices.text: Edema, erythema, and tenderness of the eyelid
Purulent nasal discharge and right cheek tenderness

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Worsening ocular pain can be caused by a number of ophthalmic conditions, such as corneal abrasions, angle-close glaucoma, endophthalmitis, preseptal cellulitis, and orbital cellulitis. Therefore, ocular pain is a non-specific symptom that, as a sole clinical feature, is not an indication for the initiation of IV antibiotics.

B) INCORRECT:

Unilateral diffuse edema, erythema, and tenderness of the eyelid can occur in any condition that causes ocular infection or inflammation, e.g. blepharitis, bacterial conjunctivitis, endophthalmitis, preseptal cellulitis, and orbital cellulitis. Therefore, diffuse inflammation of the eyelid as a sole clinical feature is non-specific and not an indication to initiate IV antibiotics.

C) INCORRECT:

Leukocytosis is a nonspecific symptom of many conditions, including viral infections or inflammatory conditions, some of which do not require antibiotic treatment at all. In this case, the patient's leukocytosis could be a sign of sinusitis or preseptal cellulitis. Bacterial sinusitis and mild preseptal cellulitis can be managed with oral antibiotics. Because both orbital cellulitis and preseptal cellulitis manifest with fever, leukocytosis, and acute ocular pain and inflammation, usually in conjunction with acute rhinosinusitis, it is important to identify specific findings of orbital cellulitis, which always requires IV antibiotics.

D) CORRECT:

Rapidly progressive pain with eye movements is a sign of inflammation of the orbital content. While fever, leukocytosis, and eyelid changes (e.g., edema, erythema, tenderness) can occur with both preseptal cellulitis and orbital cellulitis, painful ocular movements, ophthalmoplegia, reduced vision, and proptosis are specific for orbital cellulitis, a sight-threatening infection of the orbital contents. While preseptal cellulitis can be treated with oral antibiotics, the spread of infection to the orbital tissues requires prompt treatment with empiric IV antibiotics (vancomycin plus one of the following: ceftriaxone, cefotaxime, ampicillin/sulbactam, piperacillin/tazobactam).

See “Orbital cellulitis vs. preseptal cellulitis” table.

E) INCORRECT:

Purulent discharge in the right nasal cavity, right cheek tenderness, and a recent history of headaches and nasal congestion are characteristic of right maxillary sinusitis. Bacterial sinusitis is the most likely etiological factor of this patient's orbital cellulitis. However, oral (not parenteral) antibiotics alone would be appropriate to treat bacterial sinusitis.

F) INCORRECT:

Fever is a nonspecific symptom of many conditions, including viral infections or inflammatory conditions, some of which do not require antibiotic treatment at all. In this case, the patient's fever could be a sign of sinusitis or preseptal cellulitis. Bacterial sinusitis and mild preseptal cellulitis can be managed with oral antibiotics. Because both orbital cellulitis and preseptal cellulitis manifest with fever and acute ocular pain and inflammation, usually in conjunction with acute rhinosinusitis, it is important to identify specific findings of orbital cellulitis, which always requires IV antibiotics.
questions.hint: This patient presents with features consistent with right-sided orbital cellulitis. Her recent episode of acute bacterial rhinosinusitis (as evidenced by nasal congestion, headaches, cheek tenderness, and purulent nasal discharge) is the most likely primary source of infection.

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of diplopia and ocular pain when reading the newspaper. She also has a 3-month history of amenorrhea, hot flashes, and increased sweating. She reports that she has been overweight all her adult life and is happy to have lost 6.8-kg (15-lb) of weight in the past 2 months. Her pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 148/98 mm Hg. Physical examination shows moist palms and a nontender thyroid gland that is enlarged to two times its normal size. Ophthalmologic examination shows prominence of the globes of the eyes, bilateral lid retraction, conjunctival injection, and an inability to converge the eyes. There is no pain on movement of the extraocular muscles. Visual acuity is 20/20 bilaterally. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's ocular complaints?

choices.text: Granulomatous inflammation of the cavernous sinus
Abnormal communication between the cavernous sinus and the internal carotid artery
Bacterial infection of the orbital contents
Sympathetic hyperactivity of levator palpebrae superioris

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Idiopathic granulomatous inflammation of the cavernous sinus is seen in Tolosa-Hunt syndrome, a rare disease characterized by ocular pain and ophthalmoplegia due to pressure on the nerves adjacent to the cavernous sinus (cranial nerves III, IV, V, and VI). Although this patient also presents with ocular pain and features of ophthalmoplegia (inability to converge eyes, diplopia, difficulty reading), examination shows exophthalmos and features of hyperthyroidism, which are not associated with Tolosa-Hunt syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

Abnormal communication between the cavernous sinus and the internal carotid artery (carotid-cavernous fistula) manifests with ocular pain, proptosis, and ophthalmoplegia (diplopia, inability to converge eyes) due to compression of the cranial nerves III, IV, V, and VI that lie adjacent to the cavernous sinus. However, other typical features of carotid-cavernous fistula, such as headaches, ocular bruit, and pulsatile tinnitus are absent in this patient, and is not associated with the patient's hyperthyroidism.

C) CORRECT:

Accumulation of glycosaminoglycans (GAG) in the orbital tissues is one of the main causes of Graves ophthalmopathy. Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) receptors are expressed in the thyroid gland as well as the intraorbital adipocytes and fibroblasts. TSH receptor antibodies in patients with Graves disease bind to the orbital TSH receptors and stimulate orbital fibroblasts to secrete GAG and adipocytes to proliferate. GAGs are hyperosmolar, drawing intracellular/intravascular fluid out into the interstitial space and causing edema of the orbital contents. GAG accumulation, edema, and increased adipocytes increase the orbital pressure and push the globe forwards, causing exophthalmos, compression of the extraocular muscles, ophthalmoplegia (inability to converge eyes, diplopia, difficulty reading), and ocular pain.

D) INCORRECT:

Bacterial infection of the orbital contents (orbital cellulitis) manifests with proptosis, ophthalmoplegia, and ocular pain. Patients with orbital cellulitis typically have a fever, findings pointing towards a source of infection (e.g., rhinosinusitis, dacryocystitis, acute otitis media), and pain on extraocular movements. The presence of hyperthyroidism and goiter indicate a different pathogenesis of this patient's symptoms.

E) INCORRECT:

In patients with hyperthyroidism, the "staring look" is due to sympathetic hyperactivity of the levator palpebrae superioris. However, hyperthyroidism on its own does not increase intraorbital pressure and therefore does not cause exophthalmos, ophthalmoplegia (inability to converge eyes, diplopia, difficulty reading), and ocular pain as seen here. This patient presents with ocular features that are characteristically only seen in Graves disease.
questions.hint: This patient presents with features of hyperthyroidism (amenorrhea, hot flashes, diaphoresis, weight loss, tachycardia, hypertension), ophthalmopathy (bilateral exophthalmos, inability to converge the eyes, ocular pain), and a goiter, the combination of which suggests Graves disease.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of double vision, progressive irritability, palpitations, frequent bowel movements, and a 5.1-kg (11.2-lb) weight loss. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 15 years. Ophthalmologic examination shows prominence of the globes of the eyes, bilateral lid retraction, and an inability to converge the eyes. There is a smooth, uniformly enlarged mass at the front of the neck. Which of the following drugs is most likely to improve this patient's ocular findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Propylthiouracil (PTU) can be used to create a euthyroid state in patients with hyperthyroidism. Treatment of hyperthyroidism is an important step in management of Graves ophthalmopathy, as this prevents deterioration of orbitopathy. PTU will, however, not directly improve this patient's ocular symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

Propranolol is used to control the adrenergic symptoms of hyperthyroidism, such as palpitations, tremor, and diaphoresis. In high doses, it also decreases the peripheral conversion of T4 to T3 by inhibiting 5'-monodeiodinase. Propranolol is not used to improve ocular symptoms in Graves ophthalmopathy.

C) INCORRECT:

Although octreotide has been explored as a potential therapy for Graves ophthalmopathy based on its capacity to inhibit fibroblast proliferation, there is little evidence to support its efficacy. Octreotide is used to treat carcinoid syndrome, which can cause symptoms seen in patients with hyperthyroidism (e.g., diarrhea, weight loss, palpitations). Carcinoid syndrome is not associated with a painless goiter or ophthalmopathy.

D) CORRECT:

Glucocorticoids such as prednisolone are the preferred therapy for moderate-to-severe Graves ophthalmopathy, which results from inflammation and soft tissue enlargement in the orbit. In Graves disease, TSH receptor antibodies stimulate orbital fibroblasts to secrete glycosaminoglycan (GAG) and the adipocytes to proliferate. GAGs are hyperosmolar, drawing fluid out into the interstitial space, which causes edema of the orbital tissues. GAG accumulation, edema, and increased adipocytes increase the orbital pressure and push the globe forwards, causing exophthalmos, compression of the extraocular muscles, ophthalmoplegia (inability to converge eyes, diplopia, difficulty reading), and ocular pain. Glucocorticoids improve these symptoms via their anti-inflammatory and immunosuppressive effects.

Because smoking is a known risk factor for symptomatic Graves ophthalmopathy, all patients with this condition should be encouraged to stop smoking.
Image Description:

The eyelids are edematous and there is conjunctival injection. The superior sclerae are visible (Dalrymple sign) due to retraction of the upper eyelids.

The combination of these signs is typical for Graves ophthalmopathy.

E) INCORRECT:

Methimazole rapidly lowers circulating thyroid hormone levels, may reduce serum thyroid autoantibody titers, and is useful in the long-term management of hyperthyroidism. Treatment of hyperthyroidism is an important step in management of Graves ophthalmopathy, as this prevents deterioration of orbitopathy. Methimazole will, however, not directly improve this patient's ocular symptoms.

F) INCORRECT:

Furosemide is a loop diuretic used to reduce excess fluid accumulation in patients with chronic heart failure and acute pulmonary edema. Although one of the main causes of Graves ophthalmopathy is the accumulation of osmolar glycosaminoglycan and subsequent fluid retention in the orbital tissues, diuretics only have a small effect on orbital edema and thus should only be used as an adjunct to first-line therapy.
questions.hint: Symptoms of thyrotoxicosis (e.g., irritability, palpitations, diarrhea, weight loss) with painless goiter and ophthalmopathy (exophthalmos, lid retraction, decreased convergence, diplopia) are highly suggestive of Graves disease. Though several drugs are effective in treating symptoms of hyperthyroidism, only one addresses the underlying cause of Graves ophthalmopathy.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents because of a 2-day history of worsening pain and swelling in the right eye. He has had fever, nasal congestion, and pain over the right cheek for the past 10 days that did not improve with over-the-counter medication. Three years ago, he was diagnosed with atopic dermatitis. There is no family history of serious illness. His only medication is topical hydrocortisone. Immunizations are up-to-date. His temperature is 38.4°C (101.1°F). Ophthalmologic examination shows erythema, tenderness, and swelling of the right eyelid; there is mild conjunctival injection. The pupils are equal and reactive to light; extraocular muscles are intact and their movement is not painful. Examination of the left eye shows no abnormalities. Visual acuity is 20/20 bilaterally. There is purulent nasal discharge. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hordeolum commonly manifests with ocular pain. However, this condition is characterized by localized, tender, erythematous, pus-filled nodules at the distal lid margin. This patient's presentation with erythema and swelling of the entire eyelid is suggestive of a different condition.
Image Description:

Right eye

There is local nodular erythematous swelling of the medial part of the right lower eyelid.

This finding is consistent with an internal hordeolum (stye), an acute bacterial inflammation of a meibomian gland in the eyelid.

B) INCORRECT:

Cavernous sinus thrombosis is a life-threatening complication of bacterial rhinosinusitis that can manifest with erythema and swelling of the eyelid, ocular pain, and fever. However, more severe symptoms, such as headache, ophthalmoplegia, vision changes (e.g., diplopia, vision loss), signs of cranial nerve dysfunction (e.g., tinnitus, facial palsy), and seizures are expected in cavernous sinus thrombosis. This patient's presentation with normal visual acuity and intact extraocular muscles is suggestive of a different condition.

C) INCORRECT:

Orbital cellulitis is an infection of the orbital contents posterior to the orbital septum that can manifest with unilateral eyelid erythema and swelling, ocular pain, and fever, and is commonly preceded by bacterial rhinosinusitis. However, orbital cellulitis characteristically manifests with reduced vision, ophthalmoplegia, proptosis (due to inflammation of the intraorbital fat), and/or painful eye movement (due to inflammation of the extraocular muscles), none of which are seen here.
Image Description:

The left upper and lower eyelids are red and severely swollen, resulting in the patient not being able to open the eye. Orbital cellulitis is an emergency requiring immediate treatment.

D) INCORRECT:

Orbital abscesses can occur as a complication of bacterial rhinosinusitis and manifest with fever, ocular pain, eyelid swelling, and erythema. However, in orbital abscesses, more severe symptoms of orbital involvement (e.g., ophthalmoplegia, reduced vision, and proptosis) would be expected. This patient's presentation with unlimited eye movement and normal visual acuity suggests a different condition.

E) CORRECT:

Preseptal cellulitis is an infection of the eyelid and periorbital soft tissues anterior to the orbital septum that does not involve the orbital contents (see “Orbital cellulitis vs. preseptal cellulitis” table). This condition is commonly preceded by upper respiratory tract infections such as bacterial rhinosinusitis, but it can also develop as a result of a contiguous local soft tissue infection (e.g., due to dacryocystitis, insect or animal bites, or local trauma). Typical manifestations include ocular pain and unilateral eyelid erythema and swelling; chemosis and fever are less commonly seen. While diagnosis is primarily clinical, a CT scan of the orbits and sinuses should be performed if there is evidence of orbital cellulitis, or if symptoms are severe (e.g., marked eyelid swelling, high fever, leukocytosis) or fail to regress under adequate therapy. Treatment consists of oral antibiotics with coverage for methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) and close outpatient follow-up.
questions.hint: This patient has no symptoms that would suggest the involvement of extraocular muscles (e.g., reduced vision, ophthalmoplegia, or painful eye movement) or intraorbital fat tissue (e.g., proptosis).

questions.text:
An 18-year-old woman reports a 4-day history of increasing pain and swelling in her left eye and a 2-day history of malaise and reduced appetite. She was bitten by an insect just beneath her left lower eyelid one week ago and was prescribed oral cephalexin the following day because the area was swollen.
On examination, the patient's temperature is 38.1°C, and her leukocyte count is 11,200 per mm3 (reference range, 4500–11,000), with no left shift. Her vision is normal in both eyes, and other than conjunctival injection, the left eye looks unremarkable. There is diffuse edema and erythema of the periorbital tissue, which is tender to palpation (figure). Although the eye is somewhat swollen shut, the patient is able to open it. Extraocular motility is full, there is no relative afferent pupillary defect, and intraocular pressure measured by tonometry is within the normal range. The left eye does not appear proptotic.
Contrast-enhanced CT of the orbits shows preseptal soft-tissue swelling with stranding but no postseptal extension of the swelling. The sinuses are clear.
What is the most appropriate next step in this patient’s care?

choices.text: Perform incision and drainage, and continue the oral antibiotics
Admit for treatment with intravenous antibiotics
Continue oral antibiotic therapy and recommend nonsteroidal antiinflammatory medications and cold compresses
Add oral prednisone to the oral antibiotic therapy
Change the oral antibiotic to one with coverage for methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Incision and drainage should not be performed unless a fluid collection is seen on imaging or a fluctuant mass is felt on examination.

B) CORRECT:

This patient has preseptal (periorbital) cellulitis, a common bacterial infection of the eyelid characterized by periorbital redness, tenderness, and swelling. Preseptal cellulitis is not associated with proptosis, extraocular motility deficits, pain with eye movement, diplopia, or optic neuropathy, all of which would suggest orbital cellulitis.

Preseptal cellulitis is generally treated on an outpatient basis with oral antibiotics and close follow-up, but admission for intravenous therapy (initially with broad-spectrum antibiotics) is warranted in patients who do not respond to oral therapy. Admission should also be considered in patients who have systemic symptoms or are immunosuppressed.

Key learning point: The most appropriate management for patients with preseptal (periorbital) cellulitis who have systemic symptoms, are immunosuppressed, or do not respond to oral therapy is admission for intravenous antibiotic therapy.

C) INCORRECT:

Adding glucocorticoids, nonsteroidal antiinflammatory medications, or warm compresses can help reduce swelling and alleviate symptoms but is not sufficient in this situation.

D) INCORRECT:

Adding glucocorticoids, nonsteroidal antiinflammatory medications, or warm compresses can help reduce swelling and alleviate symptoms but is not sufficient in this situation.

E) INCORRECT:

Although the current oral antibiotic could be changed to an oral agent with coverage for methicillin-resistant Staphylococcusaureus, admission for intravenous treatment is the more appropriate strategy in a patient who has fever and deteriorating symptoms despite oral therapy.

questions.text:
An 8-year-old girl presents for evaluation of a painful red right eye. She has a one-week history of nasal congestion with purulent nasal discharge. During the past 2 days, she has developed fevers, and her right eye has become swollen to the point where it is difficult for her to open it.
She has a heart rate of 118 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 100/65 mm Hg, and a temperature of 38.6°C.
She is alert, oriented, and in no acute distress. Her left eye appears normal, but the upper and lower lids of her right eye are very swollen. Her right eye shows conjunctival injection. Her pupils are equally round and reactive to light. Her extraocular movements appear intact bilaterally, but she reports pain with any movements of the right eye and has difficulty keeping the eye open.
What is the most important next step in this patient’s care?

choices.text: Conduct an eye examination after instillation of fluorescein dye
Obtain two sets of blood cultures

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A red eye can be attributable to infection, allergy, trauma, or inflammation related to other systemic conditions. The development of eyelid edema and pain with eye movement after a recent sinus infection is concerning for a diagnosis of orbital cellulitis.

Orbital cellulitis, an infection of the deeper orbital tissues, is usually caused by extension of ethmoid sinusitis into the orbit. Additional symptoms may include proptosis, limited eye movements, and vision loss. Affected patients require immediate intravenous antibiotics.

Orbital cellulitis is distinct from periorbital (preseptal) cellulitis, a more superficial infection of the eyelids and periocular skin. Preseptal cellulitis usually arises from local skin infection, herpes simplex virus infection, trauma, bug bites, or chalazia and is not typically associated with limited or painful eye movements. Treatment of preseptal cellulitis may include oral antibiotics.

Distinguishing between orbital and periorbital cellulitis is difficult but important because orbital cellulitis is more likely to be associated with serious complications. The most appropriate way to distinguish between the two conditions is a CT scan, which can identify the extent of infection and also help to identify more-complicated orbital infections, such as subperiosteal and orbital abscesses.

Key learning point: The most appropriate next step for a child who has an acutely painful red eye, swollen eyelids, and pain with eye movement is a maxillofacial CT scan.

B) INCORRECT:

Oral antibiotics can be used for the treatment of a preseptal cellulitis of presumed bacterial origin but are not appropriate for orbital cellulitis, which requires immediate intravenous antibiotics.

C) INCORRECT:

An eye examination following instillation of fluorescein dye is appropriate to identify corneal abrasions but has no role in diagnosing orbital cellulitis.

D) INCORRECT:

A blood culture can sometimes be positive for the causative organism of orbital or periorbital cellulitis, but it does not distinguish between the two conditions.

E) INCORRECT:

Antibiotic ophthalmic drops are used to treat bacterial conjunctivitis but would not be appropriate in this case, given the patient’s signs and symptoms consistent with sinusitis and orbital cellulitis.

questions.text:
A 4-year-old girl presents with right-eye redness and swelling of the lid that she and her parents noticed yesterday morning when she woke up. They gave her two doses of diphenhydramine yesterday, but the symptoms have not improved. They report that she has been playing outdoors the past 2 days and has many insect bites but has generally been happy. She has no significant medical history, including skin or soft-tissue infections, and no known allergies.
On examination, she is afebrile and appears well. Insect bites are evident on her face, arms, and legs. Erythema and edema surround the right eye and involve both the upper and lower lids. She has no proptosis. She has difficulty opening the right eye but can demonstrate full extraocular movements. Her conjunctiva is slightly injected. She correctly identifies shapes on a visual acuity exam. Her pupils are equal, round, and reactive to light. There is no conjunctivitis or discharge.
What is the most appropriate next step in care for this patient?

choices.text: Begin oral amoxicillin; follow up in 24 to 48 hours
Obtain a CT scan of the orbits
Urgently refer the patient to ophthalmology
Obtain complete blood count to guide therapy
Begin oral cephalexin; follow up in 24 to 48 hours

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral amoxicillin is not appropriate for empiric treatment of periorbital cellulitis because it does not cover beta-lactamase-producing S. aureus.

B) INCORRECT:

Any obstacle to obtaining a full examination should prompt CT of the orbit and sinuses, as well as referral for an ophthalmologic examination. Orbital cellulitis is a serious complication of underlying sinus disease, and empiric intravenous antibiotics should be directed at common organisms such as Streptococcus pneumoniae, Moraxella catarrhalis, and Staphylococcus aureus. Occasionally, severe adenoviral conjunctivitis can mimic orbital conjunctivitis with lid swelling and limitation to eye movement from severe conjunctival chemosis. A CT scan of the orbit, however, would not reveal any sinusitis, and viral conjunctival culture would help support the diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Any obstacle to obtaining a full examination should prompt CT of the orbit and sinuses, as well as referral for an ophthalmologic examination. Orbital cellulitis is a serious complication of underlying sinus disease, and empiric intravenous antibiotics should be directed at common organisms such as Streptococcus pneumoniae, Moraxella catarrhalis, and Staphylococcus aureus. Occasionally, severe adenoviral conjunctivitis can mimic orbital conjunctivitis with lid swelling and limitation to eye movement from severe conjunctival chemosis. A CT scan of the orbit, however, would not reveal any sinusitis, and viral conjunctival culture would help support the diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Unless a patient has evidence of systemic toxicity and there is concern that the infection arose from hematogenous seeding, a complete blood count and blood culture are unlikely to be helpful and are not indicated. Antibiotics would be appropriate, independent of the leukocyte count. Purulent drainage, if present, should be sent for culture.

E) CORRECT:

Periorbital (preseptal) cellulitis is an infection of the skin and soft tissue surrounding the eye. It generally has a benign course but must be distinguished from orbital (septal) cellulitis, which can have significant consequences, including loss of vision or death.

Periorbital cellulitis is characterized by erythema, induration, and tenderness to palpation of the skin and soft tissue surrounding the eye and eyelid. It is typically a complication of severe viral conjunctivitis, a chalazion with secondary infection, or a scratch or insect bite that violates the skin around the eye. It may also be associated with paranasal sinusitis prior to orbital invasion. A full examination of the eye is critical, with retraction of the eyelid if there is a large amount of swelling. Extraocular movements, as well as visual acuity (to the extent that it is age-appropriate), should be evaluated. If there is proptosis, diplopia, afferent pupillary defect, chemosis, or concern for systemic illness, orbital cellulitis should be considered.

Any obstacle to obtaining a full examination should prompt CT of the orbit and sinuses, as well as referral for an ophthalmologic examination. Orbital cellulitis is a serious complication of underlying sinus disease, and empiric intravenous antibiotics should be directed at common organisms such as Streptococcus pneumoniae, Moraxella catarrhalis, and Staphylococcus aureus. Occasionally, severe adenoviral conjunctivitis can mimic orbital conjunctivitis with lid swelling and limitation to eye movement from severe conjunctival chemosis. A CT scan of the orbit, however, would not reveal any sinusitis, and viral conjunctival culture would help support the diagnosis.

Given this patient's recent insect bites and lack of symptoms suggesting sinusitis, the most likely cause of the periorbital cellulitis is secondary infection from the insect bites. Staphylococcus and Streptococcus species are the most likely culprits of any bacterial periorbital cellulitis. Cephalexin, a first-generation cephalosporin with excellent gram-positive coverage, is an appropriate choice for initial treatment.

If the incidence of methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) infections within the community is high, or if the patient has a history of MRSA infection, the treatment of choice for periorbital cellulitis is clindamycin, because it provides coverage for both MRSA and Streptococcus species. Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole — in combination with amoxicillin, amoxicillin-clavulanate, or a third-generation cephalosporin — is a reasonable alternative.

Key learning point: Uncomplicated periorbital (preseptal) cellulitis in a child who otherwise appears well can be effectively managed with oral cephalexin and follow-up in 24 to 48 hours.

questions.text:
A 13-year-old girl reports a 4-day history of increasing pain and swelling in her left eye and a 2-day history of malaise and reduced appetite. She was bitten by an insect just beneath her left lower eyelid one week ago and was prescribed oral cephalexin the following day because the area was swollen.
On examination, the patient's temperature is 38.4°C, and her leukocyte count is 13,700 per mm3 (reference range, 4500–13,500), with no left shift. Her vision is normal in both eyes, and other than conjunctival injection, the left eye looks unremarkable. There is diffuse edema and erythema of the periorbital tissue, which is tender to palpation (figure). Although the eye is somewhat swollen shut, the patient is able to open it. Extraocular motility is full, there is no relative afferent pupillary defect, and intraocular pressure measured by tonometry is within the normal range. The left eye does not appear proptotic.
What is the most appropriate next step in this patient’s care?

choices.text: Add oral prednisone to the oral antibiotic therapy
Admit for treatment with intravenous antibiotics
Change the oral antibiotic to one with coverage for methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus
Perform incision and drainage, and continue the oral antibiotics
Continue oral antibiotic therapy and recommend nonsteroidal antiinflammatory medications and cold compresses

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Adding glucocorticoids can help reduce swelling and alleviate symptoms but is not sufficient in this situation however, admission for intravenous therapy is warranted in patients who do not respond to oral therapy.

B) CORRECT:

This patient has preseptal (periorbital) cellulitis, a common bacterial infection of the eyelid characterized by periorbital redness, tenderness, and swelling. Preseptal cellulitis is not associated with proptosis, extraocular motility deficits, pain with eye movement, diplopia, or optic neuropathy, all of which would suggest orbital cellulitis.

Preseptal cellulitis is generally treated on an outpatient basis with oral antibiotics and close follow-up, but admission for intravenous therapy (initially with broad-spectrum antibiotics) is warranted in patients who do not respond to oral therapy. Admission should also be considered in patients who have systemic symptoms or are immunosuppressed.

Key learning point: The most appropriate management for patients with preseptal (periorbital) cellulitis who have systemic symptoms, are immunosuppressed, or do not respond to oral therapy is admission for intravenous antibiotic therapy.

C) INCORRECT:

Although the current oral antibiotic could be changed to an oral agent with coverage for methicillin-resistant Staphylococcusaureus, admission for intravenous treatment is the more appropriate strategy in a patient who has fever and deteriorating symptoms despite oral therapy.

D) INCORRECT:

Incision and drainage should not be performed unless a fluid collection is seen on imaging or a fluctuant mass is felt on examination.

E) INCORRECT:

Adding nonsteroidal antiinflammatory medications, or warm compresses can help reduce swelling and alleviate symptoms however, admission for intravenous therapy is warranted in patients who do not respond to oral therapy.

Ophthalmologic examination shows erythema, tenderness, and swelling of the right eyelid; there is mild conjunctival injection. Extraocular muscles are intact and their movement is not painful. Visual acuity is 20/20 bilaterally. There is purulent nasal discharge. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A) INCORRECT:

Hordeolum commonly manifests with ocular pain. However, this condition is characterized by localized, tender, erythematous, pus-filled nodules at the distal lid margin. This patient's presentation with erythema and swelling of the entire eyelid is suggestive of a different condition.
Image Description:

Right eye

There is local nodular erythematous swelling of the medial part of the right lower eyelid.

This finding is consistent with an internal hordeolum (stye), an acute bacterial inflammation of a meibomian gland in the eyelid.

B) INCORRECT:

Cavernous sinus thrombosis is a life-threatening complication of bacterial rhinosinusitis that can manifest with erythema and swelling of the eyelid, ocular pain, and fever. However, more severe symptoms, such as headache, ophthalmoplegia, vision changes (e.g., diplopia, vision loss), signs of cranial nerve dysfunction (e.g., tinnitus, facial palsy), and seizures are expected in cavernous sinus thrombosis. This patient's presentation with normal visual acuity and intact extraocular muscles is suggestive of a different condition.

C) INCORRECT:

Orbital cellulitis is an infection of the orbital contents posterior to the orbital septum that can manifest with unilateral eyelid erythema and swelling, ocular pain, and fever, and is commonly preceded by bacterial rhinosinusitis. However, orbital cellulitis characteristically manifests with reduced vision, ophthalmoplegia, proptosis (due to inflammation of the intraorbital fat), and/or painful eye movement (due to inflammation of the extraocular muscles), none of which are seen here.
Image Description:

The left upper and lower eyelids are red and severely swollen, resulting in the patient not being able to open the eye. Orbital cellulitis is an emergency requiring immediate treatment.

D) INCORRECT:

Orbital abscesses can occur as a complication of bacterial rhinosinusitis and manifest with fever, ocular pain, eyelid swelling, and erythema. However, in orbital abscesses, more severe symptoms of orbital involvement (e.g., ophthalmoplegia, reduced vision, and proptosis) would be expected. This patient's presentation with unlimited eye movement and normal visual acuity suggests a different condition.

E) CORRECT:

Preseptal cellulitis is an infection of the eyelid and periorbital soft tissues anterior to the orbital septum that does not involve the orbital contents (see “Orbital cellulitis vs. preseptal cellulitis” table). This condition is commonly preceded by upper respiratory tract infections such as bacterial rhinosinusitis, but it can also develop as a result of a contiguous local soft tissue infection (e.g., due to dacryocystitis, insect or animal bites, or local trauma). Typical manifestations include ocular pain and unilateral eyelid erythema and swelling; chemosis and fever are less commonly seen. While diagnosis is primarily clinical, a CT scan of the orbits and sinuses should be performed if there is evidence of orbital cellulitis, or if symptoms are severe (e.g., marked eyelid swelling, high fever, leukocytosis) or fail to regress under adequate therapy. Treatment consists of oral antibiotics with coverage for methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) and close outpatient follow-up.
questions.hint: This patient has no symptoms that would suggest the involvement of extraocular muscles (e.g., reduced vision, ophthalmoplegia, or painful eye movement) or intraorbital fat tissue (e.g., proptosis).

questions.text: An 8-year-old girl presents for evaluation of a painful red right eye. She has a one-week history of nasal congestion with purulent nasal discharge. During the past 2 days, she has developed fevers, and her right eye has become swollen to the point where it is difficult for her to open it. On physical examination, there is severe edema of upper and lower lids of the right eye. Her right eye shows conjunctival injection. Extraocular movements appear intact bilaterally, but she reports pain with movement of the right eye. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Conduct an eye examination after instillation of fluorescein dye
Obtain two sets of blood cultures

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A red eye can be attributable to infection, allergy, trauma, or inflammation related to other systemic conditions. The development of eyelid edema and pain with eye movement after a recent sinus infection is concerning for a diagnosis of orbital cellulitis. Orbital cellulitis, an infection of the deeper orbital tissues, is usually caused by the extension of ethmoid sinusitis into the orbit. Additional symptoms may include proptosis, limited eye movements, and vision loss. Affected patients require immediate intravenous antibiotics.

Orbital cellulitis is distinct from periorbital (preseptal) cellulitis, a more superficial infection of the eyelids and periocular skin. Preseptal cellulitis usually arises from local skin infection, herpes simplex virus infection, trauma, bug bites, or chalazia and is not typically associated with limited or painful eye movements. Treatment of preseptal cellulitis may include oral antibiotics. Distinguishing between orbital and periorbital cellulitis is difficult but important because orbital cellulitis is more likely to be associated with serious complications. The most appropriate way to distinguish between the two conditions is a CT scan, which can identify the extent of infection and also help to identify more complicated orbital infections, such as subperiosteal and orbital abscesses.

Key learning point: The most appropriate next step for a child who has an acutely painful red eye, swollen eyelids, and pain with eye movement is a maxillofacial CT scan.

B) INCORRECT:

Oral antibiotics can be used for the treatment of a preseptal cellulitis of presumed bacterial origin but are not appropriate for orbital cellulitis, which requires immediate intravenous antibiotics.

C) INCORRECT:

An eye examination following instillation of fluorescein dye is appropriate to identify corneal abrasions but has no role in diagnosing orbital cellulitis.

D) INCORRECT:

A blood culture can sometimes be positive for the causative organism of orbital or periorbital cellulitis, but it does not distinguish between the two conditions.

E) INCORRECT:

Antibiotic ophthalmic drops are used to treat bacterial conjunctivitis but would not be appropriate in this case, given the patient’s signs and symptoms consistent with sinusitis and orbital cellulitis.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a 1-day history of double vision and rapidly worsening pain and swelling of her right eye. For the past week, she has had nasal congestion, recurrent headaches, and a watery nasal discharge that became purulent 4 days ago. Her temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F). Ophthalmic examination of the right eye shows proptosis and diffuse edema, erythema, and tenderness of the eyelids. Right eye movements are restricted and painful in all directions. There is tenderness to palpation over the right cheek and purulent nasal discharge in the right nasal cavity. Laboratory studies show leukocytosis. Which of the following provides the strongest indication for administering intravenous antibiotics to this patient?

choices.text: Edema, erythema, and tenderness of the eyelid
Purulent nasal discharge and right cheek tenderness

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Unilateral diffuse edema, erythema, and tenderness of the eyelid can occur in any condition that causes ocular infection or inflammation, e.g. blepharitis, bacterial conjunctivitis, endophthalmitis, preseptal cellulitis, and orbital cellulitis. Therefore, diffuse inflammation of the eyelid as a sole clinical feature is non-specific and not an indication to initiate IV antibiotics.

B) INCORRECT:

Leukocytosis is a nonspecific symptom of many conditions, including viral infections or inflammatory conditions, some of which do not require antibiotic treatment at all. In this case, the patient's leukocytosis could be a sign of sinusitis or preseptal cellulitis. Bacterial sinusitis and mild preseptal cellulitis can be managed with oral antibiotics. Because both orbital cellulitis and preseptal cellulitis manifest with fever, leukocytosis, and acute ocular pain and inflammation, usually in conjunction with acute rhinosinusitis, it is important to identify specific findings of orbital cellulitis, which always requires IV antibiotics.

C) CORRECT:

Rapidly progressive pain with eye movements is a sign of inflammation of the orbital content. While fever, leukocytosis, and eyelid changes (e.g., edema, erythema, tenderness) can occur with both preseptal cellulitis and orbital cellulitis, painful ocular movements, ophthalmoplegia, reduced vision, and proptosis are specific for orbital cellulitis, a sight-threatening infection of the orbital contents. While preseptal cellulitis can be treated with oral antibiotics, the spread of infection to the orbital tissues requires prompt treatment with empiric IV antibiotics (vancomycin plus one of the following: ceftriaxone, cefotaxime, ampicillin/sulbactam, piperacillin/tazobactam).

See “Orbital cellulitis vs. preseptal cellulitis” table.

D) INCORRECT:

Purulent discharge in the right nasal cavity, right cheek tenderness, and a recent history of headaches and nasal congestion are characteristic of right maxillary sinusitis. Bacterial sinusitis is the most likely etiological factor of this patient's orbital cellulitis. However, oral (not parenteral) antibiotics alone would be appropriate to treat bacterial sinusitis.

E) INCORRECT:

Fever is a nonspecific symptom of many conditions, including viral infections or inflammatory conditions, some of which do not require antibiotic treatment at all. In this case, the patient's fever could be a sign of sinusitis or preseptal cellulitis. Bacterial sinusitis and mild preseptal cellulitis can be managed with oral antibiotics. Because both orbital cellulitis and preseptal cellulitis manifest with fever and acute ocular pain and inflammation, usually in conjunction with acute rhinosinusitis, it is important to identify specific findings of orbital cellulitis, which always requires IV antibiotics.
questions.hint: This patient presents with features consistent with right-sided orbital cellulitis. Her recent episode of acute bacterial rhinosinusitis (as evidenced by nasal congestion, headaches, cheek tenderness, and purulent nasal discharge) is the most likely primary source of infection.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman comes to the office because of a 2-month history of double vision, progressive irritability, palpitations, frequent bowel movements, and a 5.1-kg (11.2-lb) weight loss. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 15 years. Ophthalmologic examination shows prominence of the globes of the eyes, bilateral lid retraction, and an inability to converge the eyes. There is a smooth, uniformly enlarged mass at the front of the neck. Which of the following drugs is most likely to improve this patient's ocular findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Propylthiouracil (PTU) can be used to create a euthyroid state in patients with hyperthyroidism. Treatment of hyperthyroidism is an important step in management of Graves ophthalmopathy, as this prevents deterioration of orbitopathy. PTU will, however, not directly improve this patient's ocular symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

Propranolol is used to control the adrenergic symptoms of hyperthyroidism, such as palpitations, tremor, and diaphoresis. In high doses, it also decreases the peripheral conversion of T4 to T3 by inhibiting 5'-monodeiodinase. Propranolol is not used to improve ocular symptoms in Graves ophthalmopathy.

C) INCORRECT:

Although octreotide has been explored as a potential therapy for Graves ophthalmopathy based on its capacity to inhibit fibroblast proliferation, there is little evidence to support its efficacy. Octreotide is used to treat carcinoid syndrome, which can cause symptoms seen in patients with hyperthyroidism (e.g., diarrhea, weight loss, palpitations). Carcinoid syndrome is not associated with a painless goiter or ophthalmopathy.

D) CORRECT:

Glucocorticoids such as prednisolone are the preferred therapy for moderate-to-severe Graves ophthalmopathy, which results from inflammation and soft tissue enlargement in the orbit. In Graves disease, TSH receptor antibodies stimulate orbital fibroblasts to secrete glycosaminoglycan (GAG) and the adipocytes to proliferate. GAGs are hyperosmolar, drawing fluid out into the interstitial space, which causes edema of the orbital tissues. GAG accumulation, edema, and increased adipocytes increase the orbital pressure and push the globe forwards, causing exophthalmos, compression of the extraocular muscles, ophthalmoplegia (inability to converge eyes, diplopia, difficulty reading), and ocular pain. Glucocorticoids improve these symptoms via their anti-inflammatory and immunosuppressive effects.

Because smoking is a known risk factor for symptomatic Graves ophthalmopathy, all patients with this condition should be encouraged to stop smoking.
Image Description:

The eyelids are edematous and there is conjunctival injection. The superior sclerae are visible (Dalrymple sign) due to retraction of the upper eyelids.

The combination of these signs is typical for Graves ophthalmopathy.

E) INCORRECT:

Methimazole rapidly lowers circulating thyroid hormone levels, may reduce serum thyroid autoantibody titers, and is useful in the long-term management of hyperthyroidism. Treatment of hyperthyroidism is an important step in management of Graves ophthalmopathy, as this prevents deterioration of orbitopathy. Methimazole will, however, not directly improve this patient's ocular symptoms.
questions.hint: Symptoms of thyrotoxicosis (e.g., irritability, palpitations, diarrhea, weight loss) with painless goiter and ophthalmopathy (exophthalmos, lid retraction, decreased convergence, diplopia) are highly suggestive of Graves disease. Though several drugs are effective in treating symptoms of hyperthyroidism, only one addresses the underlying cause of Graves ophthalmopathy.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old boy presents with a one-day history of rapidly enlarging right eyelid swelling, fever, and nasal discharge. He reports severe pain, especially with eye movement, and his mother notes right eye prominence. Examination shows marked eyelid erythema, limited extraocular movements with pain, mild chemosis, and slightly decreased visual acuity. Pupils are reactive and equal.
Which diagnosis best explains these findings?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Orbital cellulitis manifests with rapid onset of eyelid swelling, fever, and ocular symptoms such as pain with eye movement, restricted extraocular mobility, mild proptosis, and reduced visual acuity. These findings indicate infection extending posterior to the orbital septum, involving orbital fat and extraocular muscles. Nasal discharge suggests contiguous spread from an adjacent sinus infection, commonly the ethmoid sinus in children. This condition affects orbital contents, aligning with the pathophysiology of orbital cellulitis.

Key learning point: Orbital cellulitis is characterized by proptosis, painful and limited ocular movement, and reduced visual acuity, distinguishing it from periorbital cellulitis, which does not involve proptosis or pain with eye movement.

B) INCORRECT:

Periorbital cellulitis involves infection of tissues anterior to the orbital septum, presenting with eyelid redness and swelling. It does not affect extraocular motility or visual acuity. Severe eye pain with movement, limited extraocular movements, and mild proptosis indicate deeper orbital involvement, which is atypical for periorbital cellulitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Conjunctivitis presents with redness and discharge, affecting the conjunctival surface without causing severe pain or restricted eye movements. The rapid onset of significant eyelid swelling, pronounced pain with extraocular motion, and reduced visual acuity suggest deeper periocular involvement, inconsistent with conjunctivitis.

D) INCORRECT:

Allergic blepharitis typically causes bilateral eyelid erythema and swelling with pruritus, without systemic signs like fever. The rapid progression, fever, and pain on extraocular movements suggest a deeper orbital process. Nasal discharge indicates an infectious or inflammatory etiology, not an isolated allergic reaction.

questions.text:
An 8-year-old boy presents with a 2-day history of fever, painful swelling around the left eye, and decreased vision. He appears lethargic. Examination shows marked periorbital edema, erythema, proptosis, limited extraocular movement, and mild conjunctival injection (see lab result).

Temperature
39.0°C



Test
Result
Normal Values


WBC
15 x 10⁹/L
4.5 - 10.5 x 10⁹/L


Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Contrast-enhanced imaging of the orbits and sinuses
Plain radiography of the orbits and sinuses
Immediate surgical drainage of the orbit

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Moderate-dose oral antibiotics are insufficient for orbital cellulitis, which involves deeper tissues and carries a higher risk of complications. The clinical presentation suggests orbital involvement, requiring inpatient management with intravenous antibiotics to achieve necessary tissue concentrations and broad antimicrobial coverage.

B) CORRECT:

In suspected orbital cellulitis, contrast-enhanced imaging, typically via computed tomography (CT) scan, is crucial to assess the extent of infection, delineate anatomical boundaries, and identify abscess formation or intracranial extension. This imaging modality provides detailed visualization of orbital soft tissues, sinuses, and bony structures, distinguishing orbital cellulitis from preseptal cellulitis and identifying complications that may require surgical intervention. The anatomical information obtained guides both medical and potential surgical management strategies in pediatric patients.

Key learning point: In cases of suspected orbital cellulitis, an urgent CT scan is crucial to assess the extent of the infection and guide management to prevent complications.

C) INCORRECT:

Plain radiographs can visualize bony structures but have significant limitations in assessing soft tissue details critical in orbital involvement. They are not sensitive enough to detect subtle soft tissue inflammation, early abscess formation, or intraorbital involvement, lacking the resolution required for evaluating potential complications.

D) INCORRECT:

Immediate surgical drainage is not justified without imaging confirming an abscess. In orbital cellulitis, the priority is to initiate broad-spectrum intravenous antibiotics and perform imaging to delineate the extent of involvement and identify any potential abscess formation. Surgery without imaging evidence of a drainable collection may unnecessarily expose the child to procedural risks.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy is brought to your clinic with a 2-day history of worsening pain and swelling in his right eye. He has had fever, nasal congestion, and right cheek pain for the past 10 days. On ophthalmologic examination, there is erythema, tenderness, and swelling of the right eyelid, along with mild conjunctival injection. Extraocular muscle movements are intact and not painful. Visual acuity is 20/20 in both eyes. He has purulent nasal discharge. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cavernous sinus thrombosis is a life-threatening complication of bacterial rhinosinusitis that can manifest with erythema and swelling of the eyelid, ocular pain, and fever. However, more severe symptoms, such as headache, ophthalmoplegia, vision changes (e.g., diplopia, vision loss), signs of cranial nerve dysfunction (e.g., tinnitus, facial palsy), and seizures are expected in cavernous sinus thrombosis. This patient's presentation with normal visual acuity and intact extraocular muscles is suggestive of a different condition.

B) INCORRECT:

Orbital cellulitis is an infection of the orbital contents posterior to the orbital septum that can manifest with unilateral eyelid erythema and swelling, ocular pain, and fever, and is commonly preceded by bacterial rhinosinusitis. However, orbital cellulitis characteristically manifests with reduced vision, ophthalmoplegia, proptosis (due to inflammation of the intraorbital fat), and/or painful eye movement (due to inflammation of the extraocular muscles), none of which are seen here.

C) INCORRECT:

Orbital abscesses can occur as a complication of bacterial rhinosinusitis and manifest with fever, ocular pain, eyelid swelling, and erythema. However, in orbital abscesses, more severe symptoms of orbital involvement (e.g., ophthalmoplegia, reduced vision, and proptosis) would be expected. This patient's presentation with unlimited eye movement and normal visual acuity suggests a different condition.

D) CORRECT:

Preseptal cellulitis is an infection of the eyelid and periorbital soft tissues anterior to the orbital septum that does not involve the orbital contents (see “Orbital cellulitis vs. preseptal cellulitis” table). This condition is commonly preceded by upper respiratory tract infections such as bacterial rhinosinusitis, but it can also develop as a result of a contiguous local soft tissue infection (e.g., due to dacryocystitis, insect or animal bites, or local trauma). Typical manifestations include ocular pain and unilateral eyelid erythema and swelling; chemosis and fever are less commonly seen. While diagnosis is primarily clinical, a CT scan of the orbits and sinuses should be performed if there is evidence of orbital cellulitis, or if symptoms are severe (e.g., marked eyelid swelling, high fever, leukocytosis) or fail to regress under adequate therapy. Treatment consists of oral antibiotics with coverage for methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) and close outpatient follow-up.

Key learning point: Preseptal cellulitis is an infection of the eyelid and periorbital tissues anterior to the orbital septum, presenting with eyelid erythema and swelling but without vision changes or extraocular movement impairment.

E) INCORRECT:

Hordeolum commonly manifests with ocular pain. However, this condition is characterized by localized, tender, erythematous, pus-filled nodules at the distal lid margin. This patient's presentation with erythema and swelling of the entire eyelid is suggestive of a different condition.
questions.hint: This patient has no symptoms that would suggest the involvement of extraocular muscles (e.g., reduced vision, ophthalmoplegia, or painful eye movement) or intraorbital fat tissue (e.g., proptosis).

questions.text: An 8-year-old girl is brought to your clinic for evaluation of a painful, red right eye. She has had nasal congestion with purulent nasal discharge for one week. Over the past 2 days, she has developed fever and increasing swelling of her right eye, making it difficult to open. On examination, there is marked edema of the upper and lower eyelids on the right. The right eye has conjunctival injection. Extraocular movements are intact bilaterally, but she reports pain with movement of the right eye. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Obtain two sets of blood cultures.
Conduct an eye examination after instillation of fluorescein dye.

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A red eye can be attributable to infection, allergy, trauma, or inflammation related to other systemic conditions. The development of eyelid edema and pain with eye movement after a recent sinus infection is concerning for a diagnosis of orbital cellulitis. Orbital cellulitis, an infection of the deeper orbital tissues, is usually caused by the extension of ethmoid sinusitis into the orbit. Additional symptoms may include proptosis, limited eye movements, and vision loss. Affected patients require immediate intravenous antibiotics.

Orbital cellulitis is distinct from periorbital (preseptal) cellulitis, a more superficial infection of the eyelids and periocular skin. Preseptal cellulitis usually arises from local skin infection, herpes simplex virus infection, trauma, bug bites, or chalazia and is not typically associated with limited or painful eye movements. Treatment of preseptal cellulitis may include oral antibiotics. Distinguishing between orbital and periorbital cellulitis is difficult but important because orbital cellulitis is more likely to be associated with serious complications. The most appropriate way to distinguish between the two conditions is a CT scan, which can identify the extent of infection and also help to identify more complicated orbital infections, such as subperiosteal and orbital abscesses.

Key learning point: The most appropriate next step for a child who has an acutely painful red eye, swollen eyelids, and pain with eye movement is a maxillofacial CT scan.

B) INCORRECT:

Oral antibiotics can be used for the treatment of a preseptal cellulitis of presumed bacterial origin but are not appropriate for orbital cellulitis, which requires immediate intravenous antibiotics.

C) INCORRECT:

Antibiotic ophthalmic drops are used to treat bacterial conjunctivitis but would not be appropriate in this case, given the patient’s signs and symptoms consistent with sinusitis and orbital cellulitis.

D) INCORRECT:

A blood culture can sometimes be positive for the causative organism of orbital or periorbital cellulitis, but it does not distinguish between the two conditions.

E) INCORRECT:

An eye examination following instillation of fluorescein dye is appropriate to identify corneal abrasions but has no role in diagnosing orbital cellulitis.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 2-month history of double vision, increasing irritability, palpitations, frequent bowel movements, and a 5.1-kg weight loss. She has a 15-year history of smoking one pack of cigarettes daily. On ophthalmologic examination, there is prominence of the globes, bilateral lid retraction, and inability to converge the eyes. Examination of the neck reveals a smooth, uniformly enlarged mass at the front. Which one of the following drugs is most likely to improve her ocular findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Propylthiouracil (PTU) can be used to create a euthyroid state in patients with hyperthyroidism. Treatment of hyperthyroidism is an important step in management of Graves ophthalmopathy, as this prevents deterioration of orbitopathy. PTU will, however, not directly improve this patient's ocular symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

Although octreotide has been explored as a potential therapy for Graves ophthalmopathy based on its capacity to inhibit fibroblast proliferation, there is little evidence to support its efficacy. Octreotide is used to treat carcinoid syndrome, which can cause symptoms seen in patients with hyperthyroidism (e.g., diarrhea, weight loss, palpitations). Carcinoid syndrome is not associated with a painless goiter or ophthalmopathy.

C) INCORRECT:

Methimazole rapidly lowers circulating thyroid hormone levels, may reduce serum thyroid autoantibody titers, and is useful in the long-term management of hyperthyroidism. Treatment of hyperthyroidism is an important step in management of Graves ophthalmopathy, as this prevents deterioration of orbitopathy. Methimazole will, however, not directly improve this patient's ocular symptoms.

D) INCORRECT:

Propranolol is used to control the adrenergic symptoms of hyperthyroidism, such as palpitations, tremor, and diaphoresis. In high doses, it also decreases the peripheral conversion of T4 to T3 by inhibiting 5'-monodeiodinase. Propranolol is not used to improve ocular symptoms in Graves ophthalmopathy.

E) CORRECT:

Glucocorticoids such as prednisolone are the preferred therapy for moderate-to-severe Graves ophthalmopathy, which results from inflammation and soft tissue enlargement in the orbit. In Graves disease, TSH receptor antibodies stimulate orbital fibroblasts to secrete glycosaminoglycan (GAG) and the adipocytes to proliferate. GAGs are hyperosmolar, drawing fluid out into the interstitial space, which causes edema of the orbital tissues. GAG accumulation, edema, and increased adipocytes increase the orbital pressure and push the globe forwards, causing exophthalmos, compression of the extraocular muscles, ophthalmoplegia (inability to converge eyes, diplopia, difficulty reading), and ocular pain. Glucocorticoids improve these symptoms via their anti-inflammatory and immunosuppressive effects.

Because smoking is a known risk factor for symptomatic Graves ophthalmopathy, all patients with this condition should be encouraged to stop smoking.

Key learning point: Glucocorticoids such as prednisolone are the treatment of choice for moderate-to-severe Graves ophthalmopathy due to their anti-inflammatory and immunosuppressive effects on orbital tissues.
Image Description:

The eyelids are edematous and there is conjunctival injection. The superior sclerae are visible (Dalrymple sign) due to retraction of the upper eyelids.

The combination of these signs is typical for Graves ophthalmopathy.
questions.hint: Symptoms of thyrotoxicosis (e.g., irritability, palpitations, diarrhea, weight loss) with painless goiter and ophthalmopathy (exophthalmos, lid retraction, decreased convergence, diplopia) are highly suggestive of Graves disease. Though several drugs are effective in treating symptoms of hyperthyroidism, only one addresses the underlying cause of Graves ophthalmopathy.

questions.text: A 6-year-old presents with 3 days of progressive right periorbital swelling and erythema following a minor facial laceration. The patient is febrile, with a temperature of 38.0°C (100.4°F), and appears comfortable. Physical examination shows right periorbital edema with a red, swollen right upper eyelid. The child can open the eye when asked, and examination shows normal pupillary responses, intact extraocular movements in all directions, and normal visual acuity for age. No proptosis is noted. What is the most appropriate immediate management?

choices.text: CT orbits and sinuses with contrast

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

CT imaging is indicated when there is diagnostic uncertainty between preseptal and orbital cellulitis or when red flags are present. In this patient, the absence of proptosis, ophthalmoplegia, and visual changes suggests preseptal cellulitis as the likely diagnosis, making CT unnecessary as the first step.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- This presentation is consistent with preseptal cellulitis based on the absence of red flags for orbital cellulitis (e.g., no proptosis, ophthalmoplegia, or visual changes). The infection is confined anterior to the orbital septum, and oral antibiotics are the appropriate first-line treatment for preseptal cellulitis in children without MRSA risk factors.

C) INCORRECT:

Urgent ophthalmology consultation is indicated for orbital cellulitis when red flags are present. This patient lacks the key distinguishing features of orbital cellulitis (e.g., proptosis, ophthalmoplegia, reduced visual acuity), making urgent consultation unnecessary.

D) INCORRECT:

IV antibiotics are indicated for orbital cellulitis or severe preseptal cellulitis requiring admission. This patient has no red flags for orbital cellulitis.

E) INCORRECT:

While laboratory studies may be obtained if there is diagnostic uncertainty, they are not routinely required for the diagnosis of preseptal cellulitis.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with a 3-day history of progressive left eyelid swelling and erythema following a scratch near the left eye. Physical examination shows moderate left periorbital edema with redness and tenderness of the left upper eyelid. The child is able to open the affected eye. Visual acuity is intact, extraocular movements are full, and there is no proptosis or chemosis. What is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Metronidazole monotherapy does not provide adequate antibiotic coverage for preseptal cellulitis.

B) INCORRECT:

IV ceftriaxone and metronidazole are used for orbital cellulitis management when there are red flags such as proptosis, ophthalmoplegia, or visual changes. This patient lacks these concerning features.

C) INCORRECT:

Vancomycin is indicated for MRSA coverage in severe cases of preseptal cellulits or when orbital cellulitis is suspected. This patient has preseptal cellulitis without orbital involvement.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- Amoxicillin/clavulanic acid is the first-line oral antibiotic for preseptal cellulitis in patients without MRSA risk factors. This patient's clinical presentation shows infection confined to tissues anterior to the orbital septum without red flags for orbital cellulitis.

E) INCORRECT:

Topical mupirocin ointment does not provide treatment for preseptal cellulitis. Initial management involves an oral antibiotic.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with 3 days of progressive left periorbital swelling and erythema that began following an upper respiratory infection. The child appears irritable and has a temperature of 38.5°C (101.3°F). Physical examination shows significant left eyelid edema and erythema. The left eye appears pushed forward compared to the right. The child reports pain when looking in different directions. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Obtain CT imaging of orbits and sinuses with contrast

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- The presence of proptosis (eye pushed forward) and pain with eye movement (ophthalmoplegia) are red flags suggesting orbital cellulitis. CT imaging of orbits and sinuses with contrast confirms the diagnosis and evaluates for orbital abscess.

B) INCORRECT:

Oral antibiotics are appropriate for preseptal cellulitis, but the presence of proptosis and restricted eye movement suggests orbital cellulitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Lateral canthotomy and cantholysis is an emergency procedure for orbital compartment syndrome, which manifests with severe proptosis, decreased visual acuity, and elevated intraocular pressure. The findings in this patient suggest an alternative diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Ciprofloxacin ophthalmic ointment is not effective for orbital cellulitis, which involves infection of tissues posterior to the orbital septum. Systemic antibiotic therapy is indicated.

E) INCORRECT:

Orbital cellulitis is a medical emergency. Urgent ophthalmology consultation and immediate management are indicated, not routine outpatient follow-up.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents 45 minutes after sustaining blunt facial trauma during a fall. She reports severe left eye pain and difficulty opening her left eye. Physical examination shows left eye proptosis with limited extraocular movements. She has a negative Seidel test after application of fluorescein dye. With tonometry, her intraocular pressure (IOP) is 42 mm Hg in the left eye and 16 mm Hg in her right eye. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While ophthalmology consultation should be obtained when orbital compartment syndrome is suspected, it should not delay the urgent lateral canthotomy and cantholysis needed when IOP exceeds 40 mm Hg.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient has orbital compartment syndrome, as evidenced by an IOP > 40 mm Hg. Urgent lateral canthotomy and cantholysis is necessary to decompress the orbit and prevent irreversible vision loss. The clinical diagnosis is confirmed by proptosis, firm globe resistant to retropulsion, and elevated IOP.

C) INCORRECT:

Mannitol is not indicated for orbital compartment syndrome. Management involves immediate surgical decompression through lateral canthotomy and cantholysis, not osmotic diuresis, to relieve compartment pressure and restore optic nerve perfusion.

D) INCORRECT:

CT of the orbits may help identify the underlying etiology of orbital compartment syndrome but should not delay emergency orbital decompression.

E) INCORRECT:

Topical timolol is inappropriate for orbital compartment syndrome. The elevated IOP is due to increased orbital compartment pressure from hemorrhage or swelling, not glaucoma, and surgical decompression rather than medical management is indicated.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother due to progressive swelling and redness of his left eyelid over the past two days. He had an upper respiratory infection last week that has since resolved. The mother denies any trauma or insect bites. On examination, his temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F). The left upper eyelid is diffusely erythematous, edematous, and tender to palpation. Visual acuity is 20/20 bilaterally. His pupils are equal and reactive to light, and extraocular movements are intact and nonpainful. There is no evidence of proptosis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation is classic for preseptal cellulitis, an infection of the eyelid and periorbital soft tissues located anterior to the orbital septum. It commonly arises from contiguous spread from sinusitis. The diagnosis is clinical, characterized by unilateral eyelid erythema, edema, and tenderness. Crucially, the infection does not extend posterior to the orbital septum, which means there is an absence of orbital signs. This is confirmed by the patient's normal visual acuity, intact and painless extraocular movements, and lack of proptosis. Treatment typically involves oral antibiotics targeting common pathogens like Staphylococcus aureus and Streptococcus species.

B) INCORRECT:

Allergic conjunctivitis can cause eyelid edema and redness. However, it is typically bilateral, intensely pruritic, and accompanied by a watery discharge. It does not cause a fever or focal tenderness of the eyelid. This patient's unilateral presentation with fever and tenderness suggests an infectious cause.

C) INCORRECT:

Orbital cellulitis is a plausible consideration due to the eyelid swelling, erythema, and preceding URI. However, this is an infection posterior to the orbital septum, involving the orbital contents. It presents with signs of orbital inflammation, such as pain with eye movements, proptosis, ophthalmoplegia, or decreased visual acuity. The absence of these findings makes this diagnosis less likely.

D) INCORRECT:

A hordeolum is a localized, tender, erythematous abscess of an eyelid gland. While it causes localized swelling and pain, this patient's examination shows diffuse erythema and edema of the entire upper eyelid, rather than a focal pustule or nodule characteristic of a hordeolum.

E) INCORRECT:

Dacryocystitis is an infection of the lacrimal sac. While it can cause erythema and swelling, these findings are typically localized to the medial canthal region of the lower eyelid. This patient's symptoms involve the upper eyelid diffusely. Additionally, purulent discharge from the punctum upon palpation of the lacrimal sac is a common finding in dacryocystitis.
questions.hint: The key to differentiating this condition from its more severe counterpart lies in the physical examination findings related to the orbit itself, such as eye movement and globe position.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department with a 2-day history of worsening right eye swelling and pain. He was diagnosed with acute sinusitis one week ago. His temperature is 38.9°C (102°F). Physical examination shows significant erythema and edema of the right upper and lower eyelids, making it difficult to assess the globe. Which of the following additional findings is most specific for orbital cellulitis?

choices.text: Inability to fully open the eyelid

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tenderness localized to the medial canthus is a characteristic sign of dacryocystitis, which is an infection of the lacrimal sac. Although dacryocystitis can be a source for preseptal or orbital cellulitis, this localized tenderness is not a specific finding for infection within the orbit itself.

B) CORRECT:

Orbital cellulitis is a serious infection of the fat and muscles posterior to the orbital septum, often arising from adjacent sinusitis. Pain with extraocular movements is a cardinal and specific sign because the inflammation directly involves the extraocular muscles and the surrounding orbital fat. Other findings highly specific for orbital cellulitis include proptosis (bulging of the eye), ophthalmoplegia (paralysis of eye muscles), and decreased visual acuity. This condition is a medical emergency requiring urgent CT and broad-spectrum intravenous antibiotics to prevent vision loss and intracranial complications like cavernous sinus thrombosis.

See: "Preseptal cellulitis vs. orbital cellulitis."

C) INCORRECT:

Purulent discharge is a typical sign of bacterial conjunctivitis. While conjunctivitis can occur concurrently with or lead to preseptal cellulitis, the presence of discharge itself does not indicate that the infection has spread posterior to the orbital septum into the orbit itself.

D) INCORRECT:

Mechanical ptosis is caused by severe eyelid edema. It is a non-specific sign that can be present in both preseptal and orbital cellulitis. The degree of swelling, rather than the location of the infection, is the primary cause of this finding.

E) INCORRECT:

While eyelid edema and erythema are present in orbital cellulitis, they are the hallmark findings of preseptal (periorbital) cellulitis, which is an infection of the tissues anterior to the orbital septum. Therefore, these findings are not specific and cannot be used to distinguish between the two conditions.
questions.hint: The key to differentiating preseptal from orbital cellulitis lies in identifying signs of inflammation posterior to the orbital septum, which involves the extraocular muscles and orbital fat.
